label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, May 9, 1947
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his brother, Armant Legendre, thanking him for hosting them in New Orleans, Louisiana, for a visit and recounting a story of two of the Medway Plantation bulls escaping their fences.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his brother, Armant Legendre, thanking him for hosting them in New Orleans, Louisiana, for a visit and recounting a story of two of the Medway Plantation bulls escaping their fences.

metadata.label: Access Note

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
May 
xxxxx 9, 1947
Mr Armant Legendre,
Otis McAllister Co., Ltd.,
510 N. Dearborn Ave.,
Chicago, ILL.
Hey,
I have been reading with interest in the Wall
St. Journal about the Roasters howling like wolves and
saying they cannot take another bag of coffee until
the end of the world. Also the retailers saying that
they had cases of coffee piled up in their wharehouses
until the walls were bulging. It is all very interesting
and I am certain that Mr Otis and Mr McAllister are also
very interested. Let me know how things are going
whenever you get a chance and if you run into any
good soft beans, hot roast sweet to the taste engage
her for the office.
New Orleans was really fun and I cannot thank
you enough. I always enjoy myself to the limit there
and still exude a little gumbo whenever my ears are
bent forward by the plantation winds. That golf
game was the highspot. I think poor Perry shooting
a seventy to win us five bucks and not getting anything
himself was the worst deal that we have ever pulled.
I am still asha ed of myself not only for that but for
the miserable appearance we put in walking with our
clubs over our shoulders while our hired employee was
battling away to make us money.
The plantation is the same as ever. And after
thinking it over I am going to give you a small inter st in
in it so that you too may have the pleasure of handling
the bulls and horses. Two nights ago two of the bulls
broke out of their pasture and rushing over to the
pasture where the oldes bull lived challenged him to a
fight. I heard this terrible bellowlng going on and
went out to find them each charging the fence on their
respective sides and buttlng the hell out it. Fortunately
they hit the fence on opposite sides at the same time
so that it did nothing but hurt their heads, the fence
being under no strain. If I had been a you ger man I
would have driven them off ? but in this case went to
bed and shut my windows so I would not the bellowing.
[End Page 1]
Am going over to see fat belly this
evening. He is engaged in some deal whereby widows are
weeping and wringing their hands. It is so envolved
that I cannot follow it at all. Guess I will just 
stick to the simple life.
Goodbye old man. I am leaving here on
the 18th. Will see you at Foxcroft if not before. 
Gertrude fixed it up so that youare staying with Olive
and Mimi at one of those swell hunting houses, with lots
of horses and servants, the kind of place that you like.
Gertie just came down from Foxcrof yester day and said
that Katherine is not only t e favorite of the school
but of Miss Charlottes also.
[End Page 2]
